immortal_asshole9666: I struggle with the small side if the spectrum. Since there is a joke about hands and feet being the size of a man's penis I do get a lot of slack from people (some I don't even know!) Some days are worse than others with dysphoria, but I try really hard to stay positive. You seem to do the same, that's why it's always such a blessing to see your posts! You seem like a very strong woman, and you're amazing to follow. And thank you for sharing all you do, I'm a trans man, it still gives me hope that other trans people can be happy, positive, and be who they want to be. Much respect 💜
activisthood: I'm a cishet and I cannot be more privileged. I'm so glad to be able to read this. I'll never experience what you're going through but I now I've read about it. Your struggle is real and you and the trans community matter. Your voices will not go unheard!

professor_charles_xavier_1895: I see you. And I totally get it. On days when I feel so dysphoric that I would practically cut my chest off, I look at old pictures of myself. I don't have access to hormones. So my face hasn't changed but I work for my body to change. When I see my real self compared to my old and suppressed self, I feel less dysphoric because I did something, no matter how little, to change. I see you. I force my voice lower on the phone, I avoid men's restrooms and hold it until I find a family bathroom, because I'm terrified. Truth be told, I don't pass. I look like a butch lesbian, so I avoid areas that are mostly populated with men. I constantly worry if my chest is flat enough, and I hope to anything that's out there someone doesn't recognize me. I see you, hon, and I know. Stay strong and fuck society's standards of how we should look.

snape_and_the_forty_thoughts: I know saying you’re so brave here doesn’t instantly translate into a complement. I can’t imagine the daily struggle it must be for you just to be seen as a human and feel the same. And I am sorry for that. You’re only as different as any two humans can be, no more no less, it’s us who are shallow. To have to be brave about things which should be so basic is a shame. Reading your post did something to me. I am not an unkind person but I’d be lying if I say that i don’t feel a little bad for someone when they don’t immediately fit in. That isn’t sympathising. That alone suggests I don’t see them as equal. And I am deeply ashamed and sorry for that. But I am trying, and you’re awesome. 💛💛
arushisc: You are fucking beautiful. Fuck them up.
izanagijuly: I’ve been having a hard time with this due to the fact that I haven’t had my hormones in months due to money problems. People call me she and her. People take double glances because I refuse to cut my long hair to make other people around me feel comfortable. I’m trying to use this time to reconnect with the feminine aspect we all have, so I may hold onto that part of my strength. But I will admit it’s hard. I’m in fear for my safety always as we all are. Being open and vocal can be dangerous but it’s also so important. It’s a shame that our rights and our lives are always in jeopardy. Thank you for speaking out, I wish the best for you and for all of our trans family members. We can find strength the more we come together. You’re an inspiration and a leader to our cause. Thank you sister 💜
